value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">23</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">there is a jolt at the points; the mind slides onto another</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">rail, lovely as the words are. To speak them the poet has</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">separated himself from the actors. He cannot yet make <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-tamb" key="Tamburlaine">Tambur</rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-tamb">laine</rs> speak those words. The play is still 
            <choice>
              <sic>manly</sic>
              <corr>mainly</corr>
            </choice> the work</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of the undifferentiated audience, demanding great names,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great deeds; simple outlines; and not the single subtlety</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of one soul.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">For the play itself was still anonymous. The lack of Marlowes</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">name is by 
            <choice>
              <sic>itslef</sic>
              <corr>itself</corr>
            </choice> enough to show how largely the play was</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a common product, written by one hand, but so moulded</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in transition from actor to 
            <choice>
              <sic>acotr</sic>
              <corr>actor</corr>
            </choice> that the author had no</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sense of property in it. It was half the work of the audience.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Yet the audience is dumb. The silence of the audience is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">one of the deep gulfs that lies between us and the 
            <choice>
              <sic>Eliza</sic>
              <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><choice>
            <sic>bethan</sic>
            <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
          </choice> play. The audience was a large one. Fifteen</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">hundred people, Dr Greg computes, was an average 
            <choice>
              <sic>attanedance</sic>
              <corr>attendance</corr>
            </choice>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Their presence, in the penny part of the house, is obvious.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It draws 
            <choice>
              <sic>pup</sic>
              <corr>up</corr>
            </choice> the 
            <choice>
              <sic>hypberpole</sic>
              <corr>hyperbole</corr>
            </choice> as a sheet of paper</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">draws 
            <choice>
              <sic>pup</sic>
              <corr>up</corr>
            </choice> fire. It makes the writer capable of great strides</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and vast audacities beyond his private reach. Yet the 
            <choice>
              <sic>audiene</sic>
              <corr>audience</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sits silent.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">To 
            <choice>
              <sic>underdtand</sic>
              <corr>understand</corr>
            </choice> the silence we must 
            <choice>
              <sic>comapre</sic>
              <corr>compare</corr>
            </choice> it</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">with our own 
            <choice>
              <sic>attidtue</sic>
              <corr>attitude</corr>
            </choice> at the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-balle" key="Ballet Russes">Russian ballet</rs> at the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-cine" key="Cinema">
              <choice>
                <sic>cimme</sic>
                <corr>cinema</corr>
              </choice></rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in the early days. A new art comes upon us 
            <choice>
              <sic>si</sic>
              <corr>so</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>surprisningly</sic>
              <corr>surprisingly</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that we are silent, recognising something that we cannot</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">measure. To <add hand="ms" place="above">the</add> Elizabethans, the power of words after their</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">long 
            <choice>
              <sic>silnce</sic>
              <corr>silence</corr>
            </choice> must have been overwhelming. There at the <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-glob" key="Globe, The">Globe</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">or at the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-rose" key="Rose, The">Rose</rs> men and women who had never seen themselves</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">whose only reading was 
            <choice>
              <sic>historyor</sic>
              <corr>history or</corr>
            </choice> sermon or some old 
            <choice>
              <sic>chornicle</sic>
              <corr>chronicle</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">or perhaps could not 
            <choice>
              <sic>r ad</sic>
              <corr>read</corr>
            </choice> but spent all their days in the</l>
